extendedIngredients.name: baguette
extendedIngredients.original: 1 baguette, cut crosswise into forty 1/4-inch-thick slices
extendedIngredients.originalName: baguette, cut crosswise into forty 1/4-inch-thick slices

extendedIngredients.name: olive oil
extendedIngredients.original: 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for brushing

title: Beet-and-Burrata Crostini
summary: Beet-and-Burrata Crostini might be just the Mediterranean recipe you are searching for. For 94 cents per serving, this recipe covers 3% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. This recipe makes 12 servings with 87 calories, 4g of protein, and 7g of fat each. If you have salt and pepper, beets, burrata, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. It works well as an inexpensive hor d'oeuvre. 1 person found this recipe to be delicious and satisfying. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 1 hour and 35 minutes. It is a good option if you're following a vegetarian diet. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 22%. This score is not so super. Similar recipes are Beet-and-burrata Crostini, Radicchio and Arugula Salad with Roasted Pepper Dressing and Burrata Crostini, and Beet & Burratan Endive Salad.

winePairing.pairingText: Italian can be paired with Chianti, Trebbiano, and Verdicchio. Italians know food and they know wine. Trebbiano and Verdicchio are Italian white wines that pair well with fish and white meat, while Chianti is a great Italian red for heavier, bolder dishes. The Mazzei Fonterutoli Chianti Classico with a 4.4 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 32 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Mazzei Fonterutoli Chianti Classico
productMatches.description: "Lots of meat, berry and plum character on the nose and palate. Full-bodied, with velvety tannins and a long, rich finish. Decadent style that I like. Serious quality for the vintage. No Castello in 2002, so this was upgraded."-Wine SpectatorColor: Deep purplish-red but bright and exceptionally concentrated.Bouquet: Extremely intense and complex with scents of cherries and raspberries accompanied by light toasty and spicy shadings.Flavor: The impact in the mouth is incisive but soft due to a substantial structure of tannins in which those that are soft and well rounded stand out. Acidity is fused with the wine's body and aids the transmission of pleasant sensations of warmth and strength. The wine features a long finish that is unusual for a regular Chianti Classico.

instructions: Preheat the oven to 350. Place the beets in a small roasting pan and add 1/4 inch of water. Cover the pan with foil and bake for about 1 hour, until the beets are tender. Let cool completely.                                              Increase the oven temperature to 400. Arrange the baguette slices on 2 large cookie sheets and brush with extra-virgin olive oil. Bake for about 10 minutes, until the bread is crisp.                                              Peel the beets and halve them lengthwise, then cut cut them crosswise into 1/8-inch slices. Transfer the beets to a bowl. Add the 1 tablespoon of olive oil, season with salt and pepper and toss to coat.                                              Top each crostini with a piece of burrata and a beet slice. Garnish with the snipped chives and serve immediately.

steps.step: Place the beets in a small roasting pan and add 1/4 inch of water. Cover the pan with foil and bake for about 1 hour, until the beets are tender.
Arrange the baguette slices on 2 large cookie sheets and brush with extra-virgin olive oil.
Bake for about 10 minutes, until the bread is crisp.
Peel the beets and halve them lengthwise, then cut cut them crosswise into 1/8-inch slices.
Transfer the beets to a bowl.
Add the 1 tablespoon of olive oil, season with salt and pepper and toss to coat.
Top each crostini with a piece of burrata and a beet slice.
Garnish with the snipped chives and serve immediately.
